The last object (rD) is an r-band dropout, with first significant detection 5\u03c3 in the f775w filter. The red circles have diameters of 2 arcsec, i.e. approximately three times the aperture diameter we use to extract the photometry.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91975272/stt2284fig6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91975272\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/stt2284fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&Signature=EjpicTBgZj32Esg5bh7mE4bdV0uo-Db5MoXAcqZW1eWViW84ljd7kDvAEWMQryRosBGwHQTfsjA61GoPJeu7t~0vmkn-kDXF5vaMSFrfJhnhMulOzvEfoaPWNCeKFbyQ~hgK1nx1pVE1Ez1~aszCaqQbbbrvhZldBRqtHrnt0TvHyUthO-5Y1XyVSKnmBThHEzYgGA2ze7rglDC4iSpQdGAuc7XIXRWIaghHwS1YBigE6THWRkC4hqO~36UyG0wSKzzXwC~ozFwJ-SLum7LsrfVjghoCPNwjmIlYOHJ6BOXcdGqaUbx6YyEXyMtEfzIL6bBy9O9KgnHgbG6UsPA6Nw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91975272&ar=1010021&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Postages of the dropouts candidate at <em>z</em> &gt; 5 in the <em>HST</em> filters from the f435 to the IRAC/45\u2009\u03bcm. The first four objects (ID1\u20134) are the candidate <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06 multiple lensed system: for this system the first detection band is the f814w, while in the bluer filters there is not significant detection (flux &lt;5\u03c3). The last object (rD) is an <em>r</em>-band dropout, with first significant detection 5\u03c3 in the f775w filter. The red circles have diameters of 2 arcsec, i.e. approximately three times the aperture diameter we use to extract the photometry.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/m_stt2284fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&amp;Signature=GVnl0Ulg6yV5yGS9WlcrnsiqfTK86JFSx-nuML67kZ0EKSguJ6QP92mwpfciX2pv-8L3~SHKV0mnM0rPTdyUeJ1RyI1K8QClIyNBnBG~BF4~3wtygq6PbnUmGdZb7XNPIbubzkPEkkr7gPrqoJFKX6XQFcz3pLZnftNgqQIlCvv6V2wUMINMGOwE-xkOHh5YX2Qur9TCy-kEWFZOA0RxuWI3HkuGrLqycV~v3DqxFHP9J6hyP5H8kZbCWXL1U3SyX8VJ3WpTE1-~viWIHm~6iwkoOX~YQ4YOSW-Aj5YkOaoJaLaSagZjhBzTG~2cMcGMMreLjAgUei8LYkM6Ip4JMA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Postages of the dropouts candidate at z &gt; 5 in the HST filters from the f435 to the IRAC/45\u2009\u03bcm. The first four objects (ID1\u20134) are the candidate z\u00a0\u223c\u00a06 multiple lensed system: for this system the first detection band is the f814w, while in the bluer filters there is not significant detection (flux &lt;5\u03c3). The last object (rD) is an r-band dropout, with first significant detection 5\u03c3 in the f775w filter. The red circles have diameters of 2 arcsec, i.e. approximately three times the aperture diameter we use to extract the photometry.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91975272/stt2284fig6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91975272\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/stt2284fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&Signature=EjpicTBgZj32Esg5bh7mE4bdV0uo-Db5MoXAcqZW1eWViW84ljd7kDvAEWMQryRosBGwHQTfsjA61GoPJeu7t~0vmkn-kDXF5vaMSFrfJhnhMulOzvEfoaPWNCeKFbyQ~hgK1nx1pVE1Ez1~aszCaqQbbbrvhZldBRqtHrnt0TvHyUthO-5Y1XyVSKnmBThHEzYgGA2ze7rglDC4iSpQdGAuc7XIXRWIaghHwS1YBigE6THWRkC4hqO~36UyG0wSKzzXwC~ozFwJ-SLum7LsrfVjghoCPNwjmIlYOHJ6BOXcdGqaUbx6YyEXyMtEfzIL6bBy9O9KgnHgbG6UsPA6Nw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91975272&ar=1010021&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Postages of the dropouts candidate at <em>z</em> &gt; 5 in the <em>HST</em> filters from the f435 to the IRAC/45\u2009\u03bcm. The first four objects (ID1\u20134) are the candidate <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06 multiple lensed system: for this system the first detection band is the f814w, while in the bluer filters there is not significant detection (flux &lt;5\u03c3). The last object (rD) is an <em>r</em>-band dropout, with first significant detection 5\u03c3 in the f775w filter. The red circles have diameters of 2 arcsec, i.e. approximately three times the aperture diameter we use to extract the photometry.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"91975273\" scrollto-destination=\"91975273\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table\u00a02.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the <em>HST</em> photometry extracted within apertures of 0.6 arcsec diameter for the dropouts selected in the field of RXC J2248. We present only the filters from f625w to f160w since all the dropouts are not detected in the filters bluer than f625. Where the objects are not detected, we give the 5\u03c3 detection limit, determined locally. The last two columns provide the 1\u03c3 upper limits for the IRAC photometry extracted within 1.2 arcsec aperture for the candidates ID2, ID3 and rD.</p></div> </div><div [5.87 \u2212 [5.62 \u2212 [5.00 \u2212 5.29]\u00a0</td><td>2.2\u00a0</td><td>5.00\u00a0</td><td>9.2\u00a0</td><td>18.6\u00a0</td><td><em>f775w</em>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/91975274\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91975275 id=\"91975275\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>QUADRUPLY LENSED DROPOUT: PHOTOMETRIC EVIDENCE</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The four high-<em>z</em>lensed candidates ID1\u20134 are <em>i</em><sub><em>f</em>775</sub> dropouts: they are not detected in the filters bluer than the f814w, in which ID1\u20133 are clearly first detected with detection &gt;5\u03c3, while ID4 is detected with detection higher than 3\u03c3. Moreover they are detected in all the WFC3IR bands (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). The image ID1 is the brightest among the ID1 to ID4, but it is also the one with a highly contaminated photometry since it is close to two very bright early-type galaxies (the distance from the centre of the closer galaxy is \u223c1.7 arcsec). ID4 is the faintest image and the furthest from the cluster centre (thus we expect it to be the least magnified), moreover it is close (\u223c1.5 arcsec) to a star. ID2 and ID3 are the images with the best photometry, since both are in isolated regions: we will refer to these images when using the photometry to estimate physical properties of this system. ID2 and ID3 are also identified in both <em>Spitzer</em>/IRAC channels, but the signal-to-noise ratio (S/N) is too low to allow for extraction of robust photometry. Thus, we extract photometry in 1.2 arcsec aperture and use it as upper limit in our following photometric analysis. About the other two candidates, ID1 is completely embedded in the light of the two nearby galaxies, while ID4, the faintest of our system, is not detected in any of the two channels.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91975277 id=\"91975277\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>Photometric redshift</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">As described in Section\u00a02.1, we compute the photometric redshifts with L<span class=\"small-caps\">e</span>P<span class=\"small-caps\">hare</span> using the COSMOS galaxy templates library and photometry within 9\u00a0pixels aperture: for the ID1\u20134 dropouts, we obtain only high-<em>z</em> solution at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a05.9 with reduced \u03c7<sup>2</sup>/DOF between 0.9 and 2.5 (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>). The four high-<em>z</em> candidates are best fitted with SB galaxy templates, the SB10 (for ID1) and SB11 (for ID2, ID3 and ID4) templates from the COSMOS library. ID1 and ID4 best fits are obtained applying the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm SB_{calzetti\\_bump2}}$|</span> extinction law with colour excess <em>E</em>(<em>B</em> \u2212 <em>V</em>) of 0.2 for ID1 and 0.1 for ID4. This apparent reddening can be related to the light contamination by the two close early type galaxies for ID1, and to the nearby red galactic star for ID4. The other two objects of our system, ID2 and ID3, require no extinction in the best fit.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For the QSO templates, we use the SWIRE QSO library including the two Seyfert templates (see Section\u00a02.1). The best QSO fits are still for a <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06 source: in particular when we include the two Seyfert galaxy SED in the QSO templates, we get a best fit for <em>z</em><sub>QSO</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06 with \u03c7<sup>2</sup>/DOF lower than the galaxy best fit, while if we only include the pure AGN templates, we still get best <em>z</em><sub>QSO</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06, but with \u03c7<sup>2</sup>/DOF higher than the galaxy <em>z</em><sub>best</sub> (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As stellar templates we use the Pickles library (Pickles <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>): the stellar SED fits give the worst results, as shown in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. This, in addition to the extended nature of the candidates, supports the exclusion of red dwarf galactic star contaminants. See Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> for a complete summary of the <em>z</em><sub>ph</sub> estimations for the ID1-4 candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As we described, we get only high-<em>z</em> solutions for our candidates when we run the SED fit on the <em>z</em> range [0, 12]. Thus to investigate what the values for a low-redshift scenario would be, we force the <em>z</em><sub>ph</sub> to be lower than 4 when we run L<span class=\"small-caps\">e</span>P<span class=\"small-caps\">hare</span>. With this constraint we get <em>z</em><sub>ph</sub> within 0.8 and 1.4 for the four dropouts, but with \u03c7<sup>2</sup>/DOF &gt;10 due to the bad fit in the NIR filters. Actually if we totally exclude the WFC3IR photometry, using only fluxes up to the f850lp filter, we get good fits for <em>z</em><sub>ph</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01.14 with reduced \u03c7<sup>2</sup>/DOF within 0.2 and 2.6: in this case the predicted NIR fluxes are \u223c1\u2009mag brighter than the observed ones. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> we present the best SED fit results from L<span class=\"small-caps\">e</span>P<span class=\"small-caps\">hare</span>. The high-<em>z</em> photometric solutions we get for these sources are in agreement with the photometric redshift provided in the CLASH public catalogue<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>4</sup></a> for RXC J2248, except for the ID2 candidate, for which a <em>z</em><sub>ph</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.09 is obtained. We check the photometry provided in the public catalogue for this candidate, and we find that there are fake detections in some of the ACS filters (f606w, f625w and f775w), due to photometric contamination in these central cluster regions, which leads to the low-<em>z</em> solution for the <em>z</em><sub>ph</sub>for this candidate. This photometry is also extracted in an aperture of 89\u00a0pixels, slightly larger than the aperture we use (64\u00a0pixels). In addition, this candidate is also very close to the ACS chip gap in the M<span class=\"small-caps\">osaicdrizzle</span> images (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). In our detailed photometric analysis of the ID1\u20134 candidates, we find that in those filters (and in the bluer ones) ID2 has detection lower than the local 3\u03c3 detection limit: this, combined with the photometry we extract in the NIR filters, places the ID2 candidate at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06 in our photometric analysis.</p>                        <a id=\"91975282\" scrollto-destination=\"91975282\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/m_stt2284fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&amp;Signature=4NlCPdeaL32OZLV1c0G9WKkrKtzpu350v5l~FD0YL8y~xevFdbGLoZgVPKD8Gx9w8HgDesAbSYh~X7yXVbksUqNkO4hlEV3nUaEtOEyPhd8T9b0I9qPe4HDwZ4lwZqnAtBt0xOhd3jz6dZjMtV03tfcZ5Vlsjmht2HCFxQxsdDj3x1NMSu-KR6VzABi~MsUilWV5coFF0zaNWbYp~Ti0hBd9DnPYBtVzptSuSXmEecqKUH1aRqg437YhZxSm3VpJl0BlUeFAeiqaLPmIVEmXI3YwrxhAqJV9JARrS~dvYcyKFu-MQnuaRZXD3k3F~LjpbN-AjRkJxXRk~7GDRu3WcA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SED fit for the best results from LePhare. The PDF of the redshift for the galaxy template is given in the lower right corner of each SED-fit.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/m_stt2284fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&amp;Signature=4NlCPdeaL32OZLV1c0G9WKkrKtzpu350v5l~FD0YL8y~xevFdbGLoZgVPKD8Gx9w8HgDesAbSYh~X7yXVbksUqNkO4hlEV3nUaEtOEyPhd8T9b0I9qPe4HDwZ4lwZqnAtBt0xOhd3jz6dZjMtV03tfcZ5Vlsjmht2HCFxQxsdDj3x1NMSu-KR6VzABi~MsUilWV5coFF0zaNWbYp~Ti0hBd9DnPYBtVzptSuSXmEecqKUH1aRqg437YhZxSm3VpJl0BlUeFAeiqaLPmIVEmXI3YwrxhAqJV9JARrS~dvYcyKFu-MQnuaRZXD3k3F~LjpbN-AjRkJxXRk~7GDRu3WcA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SED fit for the best results from LePhare. The PDF of the redshift for the galaxy template is given in the lower right corner of each SED-fit.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91975282/stt2284fig7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91975282\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/stt2284fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&Signature=SSKSwk14ux0FY9t0GPESZFBE4cYerBbL2zttQ6N2LxkDjbiee0XuWIQnQUAilFTiFsy0v00KwVX9iOidi1usTdT0PTSzpb3Y-NTt9cWZnKKeajytO0NRtQ1Jm1nRKaJp8qTcHVrHMC-FbBeIWENJaeHWniF0DDYrsmG7Wwy2NOc8lYJGcEsEIhOjMKyIFjcKim1tatUDcXtSRiBCgpZlOiYZs5GqJ5gkleHbpegfRmwv0MfRlP-ElHSQ1~JRlBbKA3xa4i0pbr9vcXu2CyRaqqreu8CYERFsj4h6PylfU6qvXtI7ZghgMU4JRqerk6G25XxbDV0IVPuwT2n45jKwKA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91975282&ar=1010021&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SED fit for the best results from L<span class=\"small-caps\">e</span>P<span class=\"small-caps\">hare</span>. The black squares are the observed magnitudes; the open blue circles are the predicted magnitudes; arrows represent upper limits in the detection; the blue, green and magenta lines are the galaxy, quasar and stellar templates, respectively. The PDF of the redshift for the galaxy template is given in the lower right corner of each SED-fit.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91975283 id=\"91975283\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>Colour\u2013colour diagrams</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">To assure the robustness of dropout high-<em>z</em> candidates and to rule out low-<em>z</em> contamination, namely by early-type galaxies at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01.3, we analyse the NIR colours of our high-<em>z</em> candidates in the colour\u2013colour diagram. In the following colour analysis of the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06 dropout, we refer to the photometry in the dropout filter, f775w, and in the NIR filters, f105w, f125w, f160w. We do not consider any impact of the Ly\u03b1 emission line contribution, since the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06 photometric redshift predicted for ID1\u20134 places the Ly\u03b1 emission in the f814w and f850lp filters. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> we show the optical and NIR colours diagram for the sources extracted in the FOV of RXC J2248, the high-<em>z</em> dropouts that we select in this field and the colour\u2013redshift tracks of star-forming galaxies (with \u03b2\u00a0=\u00a0\u22121, \u22122, \u22123) with which we compare the colours of our dropouts. In addiction, we also plot the colour\u2212redshift track for the SB template from the COSMOS library which best fit our candidates (SB11). Our four candidates ID1\u20134 all lie in the region defined with the colour criteria of equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ2\"></span><a href=\"#equ2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>): their observed NIR colours are consistent with the colours predicted for high-<em>z</em> star-forming galaxies with UV slope \u03b2 between \u22122 and \u22123. We measure the UV-slope from the observed NIR photometry (see Bouwens et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Bouwens et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>): <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\rm \\beta =3.09((Y_{105}+J_{125})/2-H_{160})-2\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>and we find that our candidates have a mean \u03b2\u00a0=\u00a0\u22122.89\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.38, which is slightly bluer than the mean UV slope \u03b2\u00a0=\u00a02.24\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.11\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08 measured for <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06. Bouwens et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) show that measurements of \u03b2 are very sensitive to accurate photometry, and that bluer estimations can be due to errors in PSF estimations. To investigate such effect, we PSF match our NIR images to the f160 image using the <span class=\"small-caps\">psfmatch</span> routine in <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span>.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>5</sup></a> We get \u03b2\u00a0=\u00a0\u22122.88\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.49, thus the PSF matching has no effect on our \u03b2 estimation.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since lensing is achromatic, multiple images of a source are expected to have the same colours, unless the source itself has intrinsic spatial colour variation, or the extinction along the line of sight is different for the different multiple images. Thus, we compare all the NIR colours of the four dropouts with each other, to support their lensed nature on the basis of photometry. As shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, the colours of the four dropouts are all consistent within four times the SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> formal errors, with the only exception of the f105-f110 colour for ID4, which is slightly greater than the other dropouts.</p>                        <a id=\"91975286\" scrollto-destination=\"91975286\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/m_stt2284fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&amp;Signature=HJrprlPjDmJKZ1XWuSXV5d-dUe2VV78f-OsfIVgcv0oR2BFRlDFeG~J1yYEtl0siO1XTPUqIhb1qp1wz9wMgbQ0vOjHGfDT3h4PpqEo-orZLF5W1-fnqdi2tqcphOwFjDind-Tde65Hxk2arN-kdMa9iGyqIMZhLSaS~dC5kMDaXylG7LHHRLd9l00go~cdzwPC1XODTx0OvjDkZsjO5j6DYkeOXL3zW2KtpWc6CUc6eI4xkI3kmCeV-x7MD2hzwyThn87~jbIX9pJ34iHPm4US8pHVxuqHWUBU58iU3nrrscWWP-g7I1-TffM5USrljUDOMch1A1TgT-6WZwgBUIg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HST NIR colour\u2013colour plot of the four high-z lensed candidates using photometry in 0.6 arcsec aperture. In the first panel we show the colours over the dropout filter (the arrows represent lower limit). The colours are consistent within four times the formal SExtractor errors, which correspond to our estimated true photometric errors in the aperture (see Section\u00a02).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig8.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91975286/stt2284fig8.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig8.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91975286\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/stt2284fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&Signature=s6W0nHSU~ppN4LYYu-6H7OT-jKYfKBI2zv85PaAORNeMTLNqwf23A2C5dnrgaO4HSBAjWXNeUOJf1RB7HjAuILUilubmSTbMz677igigUKIhvDqjZ92i45YbwzJvgj0AmP1Ge36silghjPkCIsZSGvRg1QkONQU4QB3B4i2Qx2J49h5-O22LZ7afCu~ZtmJxyz2mxjJsiMEhfZfpa76M2~p-DwJYl~-KiRSZMaj4Ax~YYEUQKoO6o4uPfMKsAFj~ZFLs35IGeqoLZJiXVOb-YAZOzCAlPaMvKNm0wYQCQjI9AioIQFhoPewvkXIvUFxFSDOK5G2jqPVZJgFiRDuRKQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91975286&ar=1010021&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig8.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HST</em> NIR colour\u2013colour plot of the four high-<em>z</em> lensed candidates using photometry in 0.6 arcsec aperture. In the first panel we show the colours over the dropout filter (the arrows represent lower limit). The colours are consistent within four times the formal SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> errors, which correspond to our estimated true photometric errors in the aperture (see Section\u00a02).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/m_stt2284fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&amp;Signature=HJrprlPjDmJKZ1XWuSXV5d-dUe2VV78f-OsfIVgcv0oR2BFRlDFeG~J1yYEtl0siO1XTPUqIhb1qp1wz9wMgbQ0vOjHGfDT3h4PpqEo-orZLF5W1-fnqdi2tqcphOwFjDind-Tde65Hxk2arN-kdMa9iGyqIMZhLSaS~dC5kMDaXylG7LHHRLd9l00go~cdzwPC1XODTx0OvjDkZsjO5j6DYkeOXL3zW2KtpWc6CUc6eI4xkI3kmCeV-x7MD2hzwyThn87~jbIX9pJ34iHPm4US8pHVxuqHWUBU58iU3nrrscWWP-g7I1-TffM5USrljUDOMch1A1TgT-6WZwgBUIg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HST NIR colour\u2013colour plot of the four high-z lensed candidates using photometry in 0.6 arcsec aperture. In the first panel we show the colours over the dropout filter (the arrows represent lower limit). The colours are consistent within four times the formal SExtractor errors, which correspond to our estimated true photometric errors in the aperture (see Section\u00a02).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig8.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91975286/stt2284fig8.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig8.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91975286\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/stt2284fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&Signature=s6W0nHSU~ppN4LYYu-6H7OT-jKYfKBI2zv85PaAORNeMTLNqwf23A2C5dnrgaO4HSBAjWXNeUOJf1RB7HjAuILUilubmSTbMz677igigUKIhvDqjZ92i45YbwzJvgj0AmP1Ge36silghjPkCIsZSGvRg1QkONQU4QB3B4i2Qx2J49h5-O22LZ7afCu~ZtmJxyz2mxjJsiMEhfZfpa76M2~p-DwJYl~-KiRSZMaj4Ax~YYEUQKoO6o4uPfMKsAFj~ZFLs35IGeqoLZJiXVOb-YAZOzCAlPaMvKNm0wYQCQjI9AioIQFhoPewvkXIvUFxFSDOK5G2jqPVZJgFiRDuRKQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91975286&ar=1010021&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig8.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HST</em> NIR colour\u2013colour plot of the four high-<em>z</em> lensed candidates using photometry in 0.6 arcsec aperture. In the first panel we show the colours over the dropout filter (the arrows represent lower limit). The colours are consistent within four times the formal SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> errors, which correspond to our estimated true photometric errors in the aperture (see Section\u00a02).</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91975287 id=\"91975287\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>QUADRUPLY LENSED DROPOUT: LENSING EVIDENCE</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Given the positions of the ID1\u20134 candidates in the field of the cluster (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>), we investigate the possible multiply lensed nature of the system. Therefore we now derive a strong lensing model of RXC J2248 to verify quantitatively whether they are lensed images of the same background source.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We model the inner mass profile of the cluster with the strong lensing modelling software <span class=\"small-caps\">glee</span> developed by S. H. Suyu and A. Halkola (Suyu &amp; Halkola <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Given information as positions and redshifts of multiple images and using parametric models to describe the mass profiles of the lenses, the code yields the best-fitting model which reproduces the observed images (through a simulated annealing minimization in the source and/or image planes), as well as a Monte Carlo Markov Chain (MCMC) sampling to find the most probable parameters and uncertainties for the model.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91975290 id=\"91975290\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>Mass components</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We describe the smooth dark halo (DH) mass component of the cluster with a Pseudo Isothermal Elliptical Mass Distribution (PIEMD) profile (Kassiola &amp; Kovner <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>), with projected surface density given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\Sigma (R)= \\frac{\\sigma ^2}{2 {\\rm G}}\\left(R_{\\rm c}^2+R^2\\right)^{-0.5}\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>where \u03c3 is the velocity dispersion of the DH and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$R\\rm _c$|</span> is the core radius. The galaxy component is modelled with truncated singular isothermal elliptical profiles (Brainerd, Blandford &amp; Smail <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>), parametrized by the central velocity dispersion \u03c3 and the truncation radius <em>r</em><sub>t</sub>.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The projected surface mass density for this profile is: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ5\" content-id=\"equ5\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\Sigma (R)= \\frac{\\sigma ^2}{2 {\\rm G} R} \\left[ 1 - \\left(1+\\frac{r_{\\rm t}^2}{R^2}\\right)^{-0.5} \\right].\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(5)</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We select 80 cluster members to include in our strong lensing model, counting 16 spectroscopically confirmed cluster members from G\u00f3mez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) and 64 cluster members selected through photometric redshift and magnitude\u2013colour cuts (see Section\u00a02.1).</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">As in Halkola, Seitz &amp; Pannella (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) and Eichner et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), to reduce the number of free parameters, we adopt luminosity scaling relations for the velocity dispersion \u03c3 (based on the Faber\u2013Jackson relation) and the truncation radius <em>r</em><sub>t</sub> [as measured in Eichner et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>)] of the galaxies: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"\" content-id=\"\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation*}\r\n\\sigma =\\sigma ^*\\left(\\frac{L}{L^*}\\right)^{\\delta } \\quad \\quad r_{\\rm t}=r_{\\rm t}^*\\left(\\frac{L}{L^*}\\right)^\\alpha\r\n\\end{equation*} </div></div></div>where the amplitudes \u03c3* and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{\\rm t}^*$|</span> are the velocity dispersion and halo size for a reference galaxy halo with luminosity <em>L</em>*, while the exponents of the luminosity relations are \u03b4\u00a0=\u00a00.25 and \u03b1\u00a0=\u00a00.5. Assuming that <em>r</em><sub>t</sub> scales with \u03c3, <em>r</em><sub>t</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>r</em><sub>t</sub>(\u03c3) (Hoekstra, Yee &amp; Gladders <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Halkola, Seitz &amp; Pannella <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), the free parameters used to tune the galaxy mass contribution are reduced to the reference galaxy velocity dispersion \u03c3* and truncation radius <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{\\rm t}^*$|\u2060</span>. In this work we use as reference galaxy the second brightest galaxy of cluster. The amplitudes of the luminosity relations are measured for both cluster galaxies in the cluster core (Eichner et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and field galaxies (Brimioulle et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). However, peculiar galaxies, as the cluster BCGs, have large scatter from these luminosity relations (see Postman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012b</a>; Kormendy &amp; Bender <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and likely a different size relation; therefore we need to optimise them independently to robustly account for their contribution to the total mass profile.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the observed fluxes in the <em>f814w</em> band as a tracer for the luminosity <em>L</em> of the cluster members. For the ellipticities and orientations we use the values estimated with SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> in the same band (assuming that the dark matter halo ellipticities of the cluster galaxies are equal to their surface brightness ellipticities).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91975296 id=\"91975296\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>Multiple images</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Since we lack spectroscopic confirmation of multiple image systems, we use the wide CLASH photometric data set to select multiple images based on similarity of surface brightness, morphology and photometric redshift: we identify 13 candidate multiple lensed systems, for a total of 37 multiple images, without counting the high-redshift lensed candidate system (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). The sources redshifts <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> are free parameters in our models: for each system, we use the mean photometric redshift of the multiple images as starting value for <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>, and we optimise it within an interval of d<em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a0\u00b10.5 using a Gaussian prior (for the system 12, since we get different <em>z</em><sub>ph</sub> for the multiple images, we use a larger interval of d<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a0\u00b11). Host (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) and D'Aloisio &amp; Natarajan (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) show that, on cluster scales, multiple image positions can be reproduced with accuracy not better than 1\u20132 arcsec due to density fluctuations along the line of sight. Starting with realistic uncertainties on the multiple images positions is important in the modelling procedure, because underestimating such errors will lead to underestimated uncertainties on the mass model free parameters. Thus we adopt a positional uncertainty of 1 arcsec on the multiple images positions, even though from the <em>HST</em> images we can estimate such positions with an accuracy of 0.065 arcsec.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> we list all the multiple lensed systems with the respective positions and <em>z</em><sub>ph</sub>.</p>                        <a id=\"91975299\" scrollto-destination=\"91975299\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table\u00a04.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the multiple lensed systems used to constrain the strong lensing model of RXC J2248. The columns are: Column 1 is the ID; Columns 2 and 3 RA and Dec.; Column 4 the photometric redshift from L<span class=\"small-caps\">e</span>P<span class=\"small-caps\">hare</span>; Column 5 the redshift predicted from the lensing model.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n [1.38-1.51]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>6b\u00a0</td><td>342.17580\u00a0</td><td>\u221244.53253\u00a0</td><td>1.69 [1.68-1.68]\u00a0</td><td>1.44 [1.38-1.51]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>6c\u00a0</td><td>342.17417\u00a0</td><td>\u221244.52837\u00a0</td><td>1.53 [1.51-1.56]\u00a0</td><td>1.44 [1.38-1.51]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>7a\u00a0</td><td>342.18005\u00a0</td><td>\u221244.53842\u00a0</td><td>0.92 [0.90-0.94]\u00a0</td><td>1.04 [0.99-1.08]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>7b\u00a0</td><td>342.17553\u00a0</td><td>\u221244.53589\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1.04 [0.99-1.08]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>7c\u00a0</td><td>342.17193\u00a0</td><td>\u221244.53024\u00a0</td><td>1.05 [0.04-1.07]\u00a0</td><td>1.04 [1.87-2.05]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>8b\u00a0</td><td>342.17427\u00a0</td><td>\u221244.53710\u00a0</td><td>2.12 [2.10-2.14]\u00a0</td><td>1.96 [1.87-2.05]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>9a\u00a0</td><td>342.18032\u00a0</td><td>\u221244.54083\u00a0</td><td>2.92 [2.82-2.99]\u00a0</td><td>2.91 [2.71-3.14]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>9b\u00a0</td><td>342.17476\u00a0</td><td>\u221244.53858\u00a0</td><td>3.02 [2.91-3.08]\u00a0</td><td>2.91 [2.71-3.14]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>9c\u00a0</td><td>342.16780\u00a0</td><td>\u221244.52628\u00a0</td><td>2.70 [2.55-2.79]\u00a0</td><td>2.91 [2.71-3.14]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>10a\u00a0</td><td>342.18078\u00a0</td><td>\u221244.54089\u00a0</td><td>2.94 [2.96-3.05]\u00a0</td><td>2.95 [2.75 3.20]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>10b\u00a0</td><td>342.17462\u00a0</td><td>\u221244.53842\u00a0</td><td>3.12 [2.99-3.26]\u00a0</td><td>2.95 [2.75 3.20]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>10c\u00a0</td><td>342.16792\u00a0</td><td>\u221244.52621\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>2.95 [2.75 3.20]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>11a\u00a0</td><td>342.17504\u00a0</td><td>\u221244.54102\u00a0</td><td>3.12 [3.04-3.19]\u00a0</td><td>2.95 [2.86-3.04]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>11b\u00a0</td><td>342.17315\u00a0</td><td>\u221244.53999\u00a0</td><td>2.91 [2.83-2.99]\u00a0</td><td>2.95 [2.86-3.04]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>11c\u00a0</td><td>342.16557\u00a0</td><td>\u221244.52954\u00a0</td><td>3.04 [2.64-3.18]\u00a0</td><td>2.95 [2.86-3.04]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>12a\u00a0</td><td>342.19555\u00a0</td><td>\u221244.53213\u00a0</td><td>1.91 [1.75-2.54]\u00a0</td><td>2.27 [1.99-2.66]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>12b\u00a0</td><td>342.19392\u00a0</td><td>\u221244.52870\u00a0</td><td>1.75 [1.46-1.90]\u00a0</td><td>2.27 [1.99-2.66]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>12c\u00a0</td><td>342.18278\u00a0</td><td>\u221244.52152\u00a0</td><td>3.06 [2.96-3.15]\u00a0</td><td>2.27 [1.99-2.66]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>13a\u00a0</td><td>342.19369\u00a0</td><td>\u221244.53012\u00a0</td><td>1.59 [1.13-2.24]\u00a0</td><td>1.371 [1.25-1.65]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>13b\u00a0</td><td>342.19333\u00a0</td><td>\u221244.52941\u00a0</td><td>1.57 [1.12-3.21]\u00a0</td><td>1.371 [1.25-1.65]\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/91975299\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91975300 id=\"91975300\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-3>Results</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">First we optimise the mass model using the 13 multiple image systems in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> as constraints, getting the best-fitting model which reproduces the positions of the observed multiple lensed images with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi _{\\rm tot}^2=16.2$|</span> (having 21 degrees of freedom) in the image plane. Then we run the MCMC to sample the most likely parameters for the model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use this mass model of RXC J2248 to analyse the multiple imaging for a source at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06 and we find that the model predicts a four multiple images configuration very close to the one that we observe (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>). We also test the prediction assuming that the source of this system is at low-<em>z</em>. From L<span class=\"small-caps\">e</span>P<span class=\"small-caps\">hare</span>, when we force the photometric redshift of the ID1\u20134 images to be at low-<em>z</em>, we get the <em>z</em><sub>ph</sub> to be within 0.8 and 1.4 (see Section\u00a04). For redshift of the source within this range, the model predicts lensed images which have no correspondence with sources observed in the field of the cluster, thus supporting that the lensed system is at high redshift.</p>                        <a id=\"91975303\" scrollto-destination=\"91975303\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/m_stt2284fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&amp;Signature=p2vPi04jPh~fNqw3fSYpkDS~LzXAuoVplK~UrTyzVvPj7~j5ekwAQ7vIxm2TZcpq38TShTE-GEue7532nCsDn~ezYmKOWVF5WUVCfGBvpQto0YwSgfBXa~2ou1YslRdB2AMI9-AG89C~aWrO82ZUjpF87MgGJ1QSfPowtMdHEsiQcZ-Ije3tADs-3SC-dRE1sDBPCM-hYofUXCm~4mvpdQeHDCoALPjH2tfaN-neEJC0i8MEkesLpIjq542FCxQzG7AK41ETE1R-FMF4DtEoTxQ0GZ-e36IBpGiUGPoEDIk-r-MScw~NkeuaN21r3~T--ab3yrptJHXilsdTCOL1qw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HST colour composite images of the inner region of RXC J2248. Left panel: critical lines (in blue) and caustics (in red), for a source at z\u00a0=\u00a06, for the best strong lensing model that we obtain using as constraints the 13 multiple image systems given in Table\u00a04 (excluding the ID1\u20134 high-z system). The light green squares show the ID1\u20134 positions, while in light blue we show the images that this model predicts for a source at z\u00a0=\u00a06 with a radius of 0.25 arcsec. Right panel: images prediction for the system ID1\u20134 from the final best model, in which we also use this high-z system as constraint in the modelling: the green squares are the observed positions and the light blue contours are the predicted images for a source with size of 0.25 arcsec. From this model we get $z_{\\rm s}=6.1_{-0.4}^{+0.3}$. We show the zoom on the predicted images (8.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a08.0 arcsec2) in the HST/f110w image. The red arrow indicates the position of the fifth central image predicted for this system.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig9.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91975303/stt2284fig9.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig9.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91975303\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/stt2284fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&Signature=ERsv7kDBlg9IUv1Tnr7XwGm~CKBgcWiFFbINJaNnf-DHBoZDzHuX8cWiHuicddjzFaEuuFR8M-TRkHiNi~kdkZwRrON8qiiT4QfvPKLT2JwLq~qjAHMcMblFN5lwyN8f5z4grIH9KykJ4zxZ1TAOIhCK4ndeOIvAWfNglRXF1ZtktwgcVM3uFG1MoAvZWua3L9bCQjKBG4JwlJKFo889~BihO39~7ut286AasSgNmSlDfl0-m1js-rFINt1wr~Dk~jnls45s4iep-X3D4RnkngVBIBoy~eI1hi39878tRhmZBf6gcQKmiAR9cE7KDmtHNAndB509uxcMc1qZd3Qa8Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91975303&ar=1010021&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig9.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HST</em> colour composite images of the inner region of RXC J2248. The red arrow indicates the position of the fifth central image predicted for this system.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/m_stt2284fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&amp;Signature=p2vPi04jPh~fNqw3fSYpkDS~LzXAuoVplK~UrTyzVvPj7~j5ekwAQ7vIxm2TZcpq38TShTE-GEue7532nCsDn~ezYmKOWVF5WUVCfGBvpQto0YwSgfBXa~2ou1YslRdB2AMI9-AG89C~aWrO82ZUjpF87MgGJ1QSfPowtMdHEsiQcZ-Ije3tADs-3SC-dRE1sDBPCM-hYofUXCm~4mvpdQeHDCoALPjH2tfaN-neEJC0i8MEkesLpIjq542FCxQzG7AK41ETE1R-FMF4DtEoTxQ0GZ-e36IBpGiUGPoEDIk-r-MScw~NkeuaN21r3~T--ab3yrptJHXilsdTCOL1qw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HST colour composite images of the inner region of RXC J2248. Left panel: critical lines (in blue) and caustics (in red), for a source at z\u00a0=\u00a06, for the best strong lensing model that we obtain using as constraints the 13 multiple image systems given in Table\u00a04 (excluding the ID1\u20134 high-z system). The light green squares show the ID1\u20134 positions, while in light blue we show the images that this model predicts for a source at z\u00a0=\u00a06 with a radius of 0.25 arcsec.
