From this model we get $z_{\\rm s}=6.1_{-0.4}^{+0.3}$. We show the zoom on the predicted images (8.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a08.0 arcsec2) in the HST/f110w image. The red arrow indicates the position of the fifth central image predicted for this system.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig9.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91975303/stt2284fig9.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig9.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91975303\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/stt2284fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&Signature=ERsv7kDBlg9IUv1Tnr7XwGm~CKBgcWiFFbINJaNnf-DHBoZDzHuX8cWiHuicddjzFaEuuFR8M-TRkHiNi~kdkZwRrON8qiiT4QfvPKLT2JwLq~qjAHMcMblFN5lwyN8f5z4grIH9KykJ4zxZ1TAOIhCK4ndeOIvAWfNglRXF1ZtktwgcVM3uFG1MoAvZWua3L9bCQjKBG4JwlJKFo889~BihO39~7ut286AasSgNmSlDfl0-m1js-rFINt1wr~Dk~jnls45s4iep-X3D4RnkngVBIBoy~eI1hi39878tRhmZBf6gcQKmiAR9cE7KDmtHNAndB509uxcMc1qZd3Qa8Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91975303&ar=1010021&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig9.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HST</em> colour composite images of the inner region of RXC J2248. Left panel: critical lines (in blue) and caustics (in red), for a source at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a06, for the best strong lensing model that we obtain using as constraints the 13 multiple image systems given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (excluding the ID1\u20134 high-<em>z</em> system). The light green squares show the ID1\u20134 positions, while in light blue we show the images that this model predicts for a source at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a06 with a radius of 0.25 arcsec. Right panel: images prediction for the system ID1\u20134 from the final best model, in which we also use this high-<em>z</em> system as constraint in the modelling: the green squares are the observed positions and the light blue contours are the predicted images for a source with size of 0.25 arcsec. From this model we get <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_{\\rm s}=6.1_{-0.4}^{+0.3}$|\u2060</span>. We show the zoom on the predicted images (8.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a08.0 arcsec<sup>2</sup>) in the <em>HST</em>/f110w image. The red arrow indicates the position of the fifth central image predicted for this system.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition, we verify that independent mass modelling with the full light-traces-mass method of Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) supports the identification of multiple images outlined here, as well as the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06 solution for the quadruply lensed source.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Once we tested that our model predicts the observed high-<em>z</em>multiple lensed system, we perform a new strong lensing model of the cluster, using this time also the high-<em>z</em>quadruply lensed system ID1\u20134 in the modelling. For the redshift of this system we use a starting value of <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a06 and allow it to vary within the range <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a0[5.5, 6.5] throughout the modelling process. After the minimization and the MCMC runs, we get a final model of the cluster with \u03c7<sup>2</sup>\u00a0=\u00a022 with 27 degrees of freedom. For the cluster\u2013scale halo, we get an offset of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\delta x=-0.6_{-0.7}^{+0.6}$|</span> arcsec, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\delta y=0.7_{-0.5}^{+0.5}$|</span> arcsec with respect to the BCG, axis ratio of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$b/a=0.5_{-0.03}^{+0.03}$|</span> and position angle PA\u00a0=\u00a0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$-37{^{\\circ}_{.}} 8^{+0{^{\\circ}_{.}} 7}_{\\,\\,\\,-0{^{\\circ}_{.}} 9}$|\u2060</span>. The cluster mass distribution has a core radius of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }16.9_{-2.2}^{+2.5}$|</span> arcsec, and it has an Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E</sub> = <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$29.9_{-1.9}^{+1.7{}}$|</span> arcsec for a source at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02, which gives a central velocity dispersion of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma = 1018_{-45}^{+40}\\,\\mathrm{km\\,s}^{-1}$|</span> for a singular isothermal sphere. The BCG is well centred on the DH, its axis ratio is <em>b</em>/<em>a</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.84\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02, the major axis has an offset of \u223c20\u00b0 with respect to the DH orientation, and has a velocity dispersion of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma =286_{-147}^{+173}\\,\\mathrm{km\\,s}^{-1}$|\u2060</span>. The total mass of the cluster is <em>M</em><sub>tot</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.24\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.01\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>14</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> within the Einstein radius for a source at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02. To compare our mass prediction with the weak lensing results from Gruen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), we calculate the most likely mass and its 1\u03c3 uncertainties by taking 200 random MCMC sample points. We derive the surface mass density and measure the projected mass up to 2.5 arcmin for each model and measure their projected mass within different apertures. The prediction from both lensing analyses is in good agreement in the radial region where they overlap, (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>). Our best model of the cluster predicts the four multiple lensed high-<em>z</em> system with an accuracy of 0.8 arcsec on the observed positions and a source redshift of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$6.1_{-0.4}^{+0.3}$|\u2060</span>. In Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> we list the <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> predicted by our final best model also for all the other systems of multiple images. The magnifications induced by the cluster for the ID1\u20134 system are \u03bc<sub>ID1</sub>\u00a0=\u00a08.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03.9, \u03bc<sub>ID2</sub>\u00a0=\u00a05.1\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.0, \u03bc<sub>ID3</sub>\u00a0=\u00a05.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.6 and \u03bc<sub>ID4</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.2\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2. The magnification of the brighter image, ID1, is not well constrained due to its position very close to the critical lines. In proximity of the critical lines, the magnification gradient rapidly varies, leading to high uncertainties in the magnification in correspondence with small uncertainties in the position. We estimate the relative magnification of ID2 and ID3 to be \u03bc<sub>23</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.95\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10, which is in agreement with the observed fluxes ratio within four times the SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> photometric errors.</p>                        <a id=\"91975306\" scrollto-destination=\"91975306\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/m_stt2284fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&amp;Signature=umruQEcYXoYRW5LkYodGd0vq-XIvHvR7BRJM454RgrMGXc36WHDVSjDKulK7WAVSOao9mY2vvGsCTj7ftZ~81Uu6ThBp-3BEve7J20vsFLE0PtTe5-XbeaRN4FRopoZ7mY9~-QHleutGmTG3wBfGQ3XpT37gwS2Z2knkRHe0EmhbZJVV9q~Q1Q3UzrleYtWSfvFWXDw2-MXW-2jqch76sEaqtGCOkcyTrH2BfbdDoRbiX9LIMkpeNi4p0J~V1ES1YjC5Y0EaBGqdGmk0MVApWRktvc~i0lpKYq91OdU3qsU8yGosZBsYoUjYAN3W8VzdBPv4YpV90aegxg0ugP8kGQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cumulative projected mass profile of RXC J2248. We compare results from the strong lensing (this work) and weak lensing Gruen et\u00a0al. (2013) analysis. In yellow we plot the most likely mass from the strong lensing analysis with 1\u03c3 uncertainties (red area) obtained from the MCMC sample. In black we plot the weak lensing measurements from Gruen et\u00a0al. (2013) with the uncertainties from the best NFW fit model (blue area). The predictions from both lensing analyses are in good agreement with the radial region where they overlap.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig10.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91975306/stt2284fig10.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig10.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91975306\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/stt2284fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&Signature=tbiddWo135inocv7KUepsncGS7fc0fQqicnUwyOgUgW4kyxu3~UhoLn6w03SU6I4KvmcnEtlTMzbL50OFNNYevsPqn568MqsNhi~lE7Z13syq1WuUilIwNTBYSfEUn5vmW8XgPRpPIxIffGBsvhCzngk7ZoI~q9CrDVUgqNRZPvMsY~UxqCub4ciwm8EHwHuPoSSuH-3Mp9cbj25cRYiL6DOza1VEBEml40Dh1anNnKEvItquWqVx1vFe1RW7SxcgCBKzD~9IkzYTHpefG1dxcIXtTxJiqJAhNdPEiAudDbiCoXUdkH03VGP~gy~az8Sm7nF4lko4BNBX84KNYTzKg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91975306&ar=1010021&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig10.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cumulative projected mass profile of RXC J2248. We compare results from the strong lensing (this work) and weak lensing Gruen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) analysis. In yellow we plot the most likely mass from the strong lensing analysis with 1\u03c3 uncertainties (red area) obtained from the MCMC sample. In black we plot the weak lensing measurements from Gruen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) with the uncertainties from the best NFW fit model (blue area). The predictions from both lensing analyses are in good agreement with the radial region where they overlap.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/m_stt2284fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&amp;Signature=umruQEcYXoYRW5LkYodGd0vq-XIvHvR7BRJM454RgrMGXc36WHDVSjDKulK7WAVSOao9mY2vvGsCTj7ftZ~81Uu6ThBp-3BEve7J20vsFLE0PtTe5-XbeaRN4FRopoZ7mY9~-QHleutGmTG3wBfGQ3XpT37gwS2Z2knkRHe0EmhbZJVV9q~Q1Q3UzrleYtWSfvFWXDw2-MXW-2jqch76sEaqtGCOkcyTrH2BfbdDoRbiX9LIMkpeNi4p0J~V1ES1YjC5Y0EaBGqdGmk0MVApWRktvc~i0lpKYq91OdU3qsU8yGosZBsYoUjYAN3W8VzdBPv4YpV90aegxg0ugP8kGQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cumulative projected mass profile of RXC J2248. We compare results from the strong lensing (this work) and weak lensing Gruen et\u00a0al. (2013) analysis. In yellow we plot the most likely mass from the strong lensing analysis with 1\u03c3 uncertainties (red area) obtained from the MCMC sample. In black we plot the weak lensing measurements from Gruen et\u00a0al. (2013) with the uncertainties from the best NFW fit model (blue area). The predictions from both lensing analyses are in good agreement with the radial region where they overlap.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig10.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91975306/stt2284fig10.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig10.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91975306\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/stt2284fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&Signature=tbiddWo135inocv7KUepsncGS7fc0fQqicnUwyOgUgW4kyxu3~UhoLn6w03SU6I4KvmcnEtlTMzbL50OFNNYevsPqn568MqsNhi~lE7Z13syq1WuUilIwNTBYSfEUn5vmW8XgPRpPIxIffGBsvhCzngk7ZoI~q9CrDVUgqNRZPvMsY~UxqCub4ciwm8EHwHuPoSSuH-3Mp9cbj25cRYiL6DOza1VEBEml40Dh1anNnKEvItquWqVx1vFe1RW7SxcgCBKzD~9IkzYTHpefG1dxcIXtTxJiqJAhNdPEiAudDbiCoXUdkH03VGP~gy~az8Sm7nF4lko4BNBX84KNYTzKg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91975306&ar=1010021&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig10.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cumulative projected mass profile of RXC J2248. We compare results from the strong lensing (this work) and weak lensing Gruen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) analysis. In yellow we plot the most likely mass from the strong lensing analysis with 1\u03c3 uncertainties (red area) obtained from the MCMC sample. In black we plot the weak lensing measurements from Gruen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) with the uncertainties from the best NFW fit model (blue area). The predictions from both lensing analyses are in good agreement with the radial region where they overlap.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, comparing the previous model, and the final one with the high-<em>z</em> system, we found that including or omitting the high-redshift candidate system does not significantly alter the results for the cluster mass model.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91975308 id=\"91975308\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>THE CENTRAL IMAGE</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">As we show in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>, our final best model predicts a central fifth image for our high-<em>z</em> system, as we also expect from lensing theory. This central image is \u223c3.5 arcsec away from the BCG, thus it is completely embedded in the BCG light. However, we find that, in the NIR images of the CLASH data set, a source is detected at the position predicted for the central image (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>). We call this source ID0. To investigate this source we subtract the BCG light from our images. Within CLASH, we use the isophote fitting routine, SNUC,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>6</sup></a> which is part of the XVISTA image processing system, to derive two-dimensional models of all early-type BCGs in the CLASH clusters. SNUC is capable of simultaneously obtaining the best non-linear least-squares fits to the two-dimensional surface brightness distributions in multiple, overlapping galaxies (see Lauer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1986</a>). We perform these fits independently in the 12 <em>HST</em> passbands acquired with the ACS/WFC and WFC3/IR cameras (the BCGs are typically not dominant in the four WFC3/UVIS bands used in CLASH). Up to 10 of the brightest galaxies, including the BCG, are fitted. Other objects in this region are masked prior to the fit.</p>                        <a id=\"91975310\" scrollto-destination=\"91975310\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/m_stt2284fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&amp;Signature=wsyFSJ8fgJzPWnqdJzkhURZBcsVq737msMSq8iwXP1-866np5qU98iDMC1lonthpsGVh7u9dZAZlRt-bgcek~rxdZObz3J~07WHro2mCYNAqYlsENs9i9Z0TRyS0qFZmohoneF2taMIp8DYu3nKmqhHueDfV~Umr9AioUkfo9~y4DgB3KtZyfd0b8~CUW14OW3aFxEzuHxD6ufyOVfqfd-~uhkx~iubZgVnYLEoAMZCIpMWQw1g41wUZe6G~3jhzDTTiuVPBdAjv0pdfxtIlrVX0kdDJtClCZ91mX~6Kyl-m1emZGnaus5sAf7ZnsvHoMxHGhqyHJ2QkVafLzg0xig__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Postage stamps of the central image that we discover thanks to the strong lensing prediction and the subtraction of the cluster BCG. Upper panel: HST/ACS and HST/WFC3IR postage of 4\u00a0\u00d7\u00a04 arcsec2 centred on the position predicted from lensing for the fifth image of the high-z system, where a source is actually observed in the NIR images. Lower panel: same as the upper panel, but for the images after the BCG subtraction: in this case there is a clear detection in the NIR filters, but also in the f814w and f850lp filters there are residuals left after the BCG subtraction.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig11.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91975310/stt2284fig11.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig11.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91975310\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/stt2284fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&Signature=SEDI0govryIEgUePYVEypTLUTNtIrX9KR6os5dTUiL-QN-VyPU5T7PBAMq3WqGRc49Nm-n~2SOUePPH2SZqjgO9pkvYC7TA5fGuodKjEDnWxmtVXz4cYDy16TvWZCFcKDQATkzntawam2GnQA4cMb7d6HsMa02iboZ0uw~2zsLkL9eDj7iJcArv8186DxX07H3Egx65tLx3217LDPsPGBPTr9xNlL~PBVOA3TVA0dvMTo5l-gehCXcJrEzjNZr4UfI1-kZlqDI3Eq6w8bd2E96p2N6HUd6JUtZItsFXYVvklVWrk-9Pqg5yWa-2QEggOIV6qYhr2nQw6x5e~Nadrlw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91975310&ar=1010021&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig11.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Postage stamps of the central image that we discover thanks to the strong lensing prediction and the subtraction of the cluster BCG. Upper panel: <em>HST</em>/ACS and <em>HST</em>/WFC3IR postage of 4\u00a0\u00d7\u00a04 arcsec<sup>2</sup> centred on the position predicted from lensing for the fifth image of the high-<em>z</em> system, where a source is actually observed in the NIR images. Lower panel: same as the upper panel, but for the images after the BCG subtraction: in this case there is a clear detection in the NIR filters, but also in the f814w and f850lp filters there are residuals left after the BCG subtraction.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/m_stt2284fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&amp;Signature=wsyFSJ8fgJzPWnqdJzkhURZBcsVq737msMSq8iwXP1-866np5qU98iDMC1lonthpsGVh7u9dZAZlRt-bgcek~rxdZObz3J~07WHro2mCYNAqYlsENs9i9Z0TRyS0qFZmohoneF2taMIp8DYu3nKmqhHueDfV~Umr9AioUkfo9~y4DgB3KtZyfd0b8~CUW14OW3aFxEzuHxD6ufyOVfqfd-~uhkx~iubZgVnYLEoAMZCIpMWQw1g41wUZe6G~3jhzDTTiuVPBdAjv0pdfxtIlrVX0kdDJtClCZ91mX~6Kyl-m1emZGnaus5sAf7ZnsvHoMxHGhqyHJ2QkVafLzg0xig__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Postage stamps of the central image that we discover thanks to the strong lensing prediction and the subtraction of the cluster BCG. Upper panel: HST/ACS and HST/WFC3IR postage of 4\u00a0\u00d7\u00a04 arcsec2 centred on the position predicted from lensing for the fifth image of the high-z system, where a source is actually observed in the NIR images. Lower panel: same as the upper panel, but for the images after the BCG subtraction: in this case there is a clear detection in the NIR filters, but also in the f814w and f850lp filters there are residuals left after the BCG subtraction.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig11.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91975310/stt2284fig11.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig11.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91975310\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/stt2284fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&Signature=SEDI0govryIEgUePYVEypTLUTNtIrX9KR6os5dTUiL-QN-VyPU5T7PBAMq3WqGRc49Nm-n~2SOUePPH2SZqjgO9pkvYC7TA5fGuodKjEDnWxmtVXz4cYDy16TvWZCFcKDQATkzntawam2GnQA4cMb7d6HsMa02iboZ0uw~2zsLkL9eDj7iJcArv8186DxX07H3Egx65tLx3217LDPsPGBPTr9xNlL~PBVOA3TVA0dvMTo5l-gehCXcJrEzjNZr4UfI1-kZlqDI3Eq6w8bd2E96p2N6HUd6JUtZItsFXYVvklVWrk-9Pqg5yWa-2QEggOIV6qYhr2nQw6x5e~Nadrlw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91975310&ar=1010021&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig11.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Postage stamps of the central image that we discover thanks to the strong lensing prediction and the subtraction of the cluster BCG. Upper panel: <em>HST</em>/ACS and <em>HST</em>/WFC3IR postage of 4\u00a0\u00d7\u00a04 arcsec<sup>2</sup> centred on the position predicted from lensing for the fifth image of the high-<em>z</em> system, where a source is actually observed in the NIR images. Lower panel: same as the upper panel, but for the images after the BCG subtraction: in this case there is a clear detection in the NIR filters, but also in the f814w and f850lp filters there are residuals left after the BCG subtraction.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the specific case of RXC J2248, we only fit the BCG and its three closest satellite galaxies. Residuals were typically less than 0.001\u2009mag, indicating that all four of the fitted galaxies are consistent with the concentric elliptical isophote assumption used in this procedure. SNUC, however, does allow the ellipticity and position angle of the isophotes to vary with the semi-major axis.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a> we show the cutout of the central image ID0 of our lensed system for the <em>HST</em>/ACS and <em>HST</em>/WFC3IR images after the subtraction of the BCG and the satellite galaxies. After removing the BCG, ID0 is clearly detected in all the NIR <em>HST</em> filters, while its detection in the f814w and f850lp filters is difficult to claim, given the high noise fluctuations in this two bands and their low S/N. Despite the fact that the photometry of this object is highly contaminated by the BCG light, we try to estimate the <em>z</em><sub>ph</sub> using the photometry extracted from the images after the BCG subtraction. The result from L<span class=\"small-caps\">e</span>P<span class=\"small-caps\">hare</span> gives <em>z</em><sub>ph</sub>\u00a0=\u00a05.88 as the best solution for the galaxy SED fit. Due to the noisy photometry, the PDF(<em>z</em>) is quite broad, but given the good lensing prediction for this image, and also the best <em>z</em><sub>ph</sub> value, we are confident that this source is actually the central image of our system. For this image, our best strong lensing model predicts a magnification of 2.12\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.68. From the lensing model, the magnifications of ID2 and ID3 relative to ID0 are \u03bc<sub>20</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.2 and \u03bc<sub>30</sub>2.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.9, respectively. These magnifications are in agreement within the uncertainties with the mean ratios of the observed fluxes in the NIR filters (from f105w to f160w), which are <em>f</em><sub>20</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.1\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3 and <em>f</em><sub>30</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91975313 id=\"91975313\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>PHYSICAL PROPERTIES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we estimate some physical properties of the high-<em>z</em> galaxy quintuply lensed in the field of RXC J2248. As noted in the previous sections, the images ID2 and ID3 are the ones with the best photometry, which do not suffer any contamination by nearby sources, so we focus on these images to estimate physical properties based on photometry. In Section\u00a05, we estimate the magnification for ID2 and ID3 to be \u03bc<sub>ID2</sub>\u00a0=\u00a05.1\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.0 and \u03bc<sub>ID3</sub>\u00a0=\u00a05.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.6. From the best L<span class=\"small-caps\">e</span>P<span class=\"small-caps\">hare</span> galaxy SED fit, we extract the UV absolute magnitude <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M^{\\rm AB}_{1600}$|</span> for these images, and after correcting for the magnification, we get delensed absolute UV magnitudes of \u221219.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2 and \u221219.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.1, respectively, for ID2 and ID3. Comparing these values with the luminosity function at redshift <em>z</em>=6 as estimated in Bouwens et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), our candidates have <em>L</em><sub>UV</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.5<em>L</em>*.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">In order to derive the physical properties of the system ID2&amp;3 we perform a fit of model SEDs to the colours of ID2&amp;3 with the SED-fitting routine SED<span class=\"small-caps\">fit</span> (Drory, Bender &amp; Hopp <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>). It performs a \u03c7<sup>2</sup> fit of model SEDs to the observed photometry, concurrently allowing reddening by dust following the law of Calzetti et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>). As a basis for the template set for the fitting we use the single stellar population (SSP) model SEDs of Bruzual &amp; Charlot (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>, hereafter BC03) with a Chabrier IMF (Chabrier <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) and Padova 1994 evolutionary tracks. From these we create composite stellar populations (CSPs) with the software <span class=\"small-caps\">galaxev</span>.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>7</sup></a> The star formation history (SFH) of galaxies is commonly described by a so-called \u2018\u03c4 model\u2019 that follows: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ6\" content-id=\"equ6\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\mathrm{SFR}\\propto \\exp (-t/\\tau ),\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(6)</span></div>where <em>SFR</em> denotes the star formation rate, and \u03c4 the (positive) <em>e</em>-folding time-scale. <em>t</em> is the time that has elapsed since the start of star formation, i.e. the age of the galaxy. This function describes well the SFHs of local galaxies, but likely does not hold for <em>z</em> \u2273\u00a01 (e.g. Maraston et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Lilly et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). In fact, Maraston et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) showed that fitting model SEDs with exponentially decreasing SFRs to star-forming galaxies at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02 yields unrealistic young ages because the galaxy spectrum is then dominated by the young stellar population. Moreover, they showed that \u03c4 models with negative \u03c4 lead to more physical results.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Here we create CSPs for \u03c4 models with both positive and negative \u03c4 (and therefore decreasing and increasing SFR), as these should set lower and upper limits to the SFR of the investigated galaxy. We generate CSPs with metallicities of <em>Z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.0001, 0.0004, 0.004, 0.008, 0.02\u2009(Z<sub>\u2299</sub>), 0.05 and <em>e</em>-folding time-scales of \u03c4\u00a0=\u00a0\u00b10.01, \u00b10.1, \u00b10.5, \u00b11.0, \u00b12.0, \u00b13.0, \u00b14.0 and \u00b15.0\u2009Gyr for the \u03c4 model. The created CSPs were extracted at 24 different ages evenly distributed in logarithmic space between 0.1\u2009Myr and 3\u2009Gyr. Additionally to the CSPs, we extract SSPs with the same metallicities and ages. We set the redshift of the system ID1\u20134 to <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a05.9. For model ages that are higher than the age of the Universe at redshift 5.9 the SED fitting code will assign probabilities of zero. The extinction is allowed to take values between <em>A</em><sub>V</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.0 and 3.0 with steps of 0.1.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We perform the SED fitting for model sets containing the SSPs and CSPs with increasing and decreasing SFH separately, and afterwards with all models combined. The results are summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"91975318\" scrollto-destination=\"91975318\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl5\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" data-id=\"tbl5\"><span class=\"label\">Table\u00a05.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fitting parameters from SED fitting for CSPs, SSPs, and all models combined. Positive values for \u03c4 stand for an exponentially decreasing SFR, SFR \u221d exp\u2009(\u2212<em>t</em>/\u03c4), while negative values denote an increasing SFR. We interpolate the PDF of model ages (see also Figs\u00a0A5 to A8) and calculate the age interval within which the probability of a fit is 95.45\u2009 per cent (corresponding to a 2\u03c3 confidence interval). These 2\u03c3 intervals are given in brackets in the column \u2018age\u2019. The same is done for the masses, where the corresponding intervals are in column \u2018<em>M</em><sub>*</sub>\u2019. Note that the age and mass values of the best-fitting model do not necessarily lie in the calculated intervals.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span [0.033,0.26]\u00a0</td><td>\u22122.90\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>0.2\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>ID3\u00a0</td><td>SSP\u00a0</td><td>0.005\u00a0</td><td>1.5 [0.1,330]\u00a0</td><td>0.21 [0.058,0.75]\u00a0</td><td>\u22122.64\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>0.4\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/91975318\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Using the SSPs models, the best fits yield subsolar metallicities (0.2 and 0.005\u2009Z<sub>\u2299</sub> for ID2 and ID3, respectively) and very young ages (0.1 and 1.5\u2009Myr for ID2 and ID3, respectively). The results when using the CSPs with increasing and decreasing SFR are similar to one another. The best fits yield the same values for the metallicities (0.2 and 0.005\u2009Z<sub>\u2299</sub>) and comparable small ages (0.5 and 1.5\u2009Myr). In summary, for the three different model sets (SSPs, and CSPs with \u03c4 \u2276 0) the results for metallicities, extinctions and ages are essentially the same (except for the age of ID2, which is 0.1\u2009Myr for the CSPs, and 0.5\u2009Myr for the SSPs). Actually, this is what we would expect given the small ages resulting from the best fits. Within these short time-scales (<em>t</em>\u00a0\u226a\u00a0\u03c4) the galaxies could not evolve significantly which is why the stellar populations (and therefore SEDs) of the CSPs are very similar to one another and also to the SSPs. When including all models (CSPs and SSPs) in the SED fitting, we get that ID2 is better fitted by a CSP model with increasing SFR, while an SSP model is preferred for ID3. In any case, the differences in the stellar populations are, as mentioned above, not very high at these young ages which is why the results for ID2&amp;3 are in good agreement.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">All the results are shown in greater detail in Appendix A, Figs <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a> to <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig17\" data-open=\"fig17\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A4</a>, where we plot the best-fitting SEDs and the likelihood distributions in parameter space, as well as in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig19\" data-open=\"fig19\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A5</a> to <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig21\" data-open=\"fig21\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A8</a>, which display the PDFs of the model ages. Through interpolation of the age PDF, we calculate that ID2&amp;3 have ages within the interval of [0.1,330]\u2009Myr (centred on the PDF) at a 95.45\u2009 per cent (2\u03c3) confidence. The same was done for the masses, which we estimate to be within [0.3, 7.5]\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>8</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> at the same level of confidence. The best-fitting masses and the age and mass intervals are also summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. The \u03c7<sup>2</sup> values of all fitting results lie between 10 and 12.7 and differ only marginally when the underlying model set is changed.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We furthermore estimate the UV slope \u03b2 (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>) of the best-fitting SED of each run by a linear fit of log\u2009(\u03bb) versus log\u2009(<em>F</em><sub>\u03bb</sub>) within \u03bb \u2208 [1276, 2490]\u2009\u00c5 (see Calzetti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>), getting results which are in total agreement with \u03b2\u00a0=\u00a0\u22122.89\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.38 estimated using the observed NIR colours in Section\u00a04.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We also combine the likelihoods from the SED fits of the two candidates, and the results for masses and ages are the same as the previous ones. Moreover, we repeat the SED fits with SSP and CPS, using this time the combined photometry of the two lensed images ID2&amp;3, and the SED fits lead to the same constraints on masses and ages.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, we investigate whether the inclusion of the additional information from the shallow IRAC data affects our results. We repeat the previous SED fitting but include the upper limits estimated in the 3.6\u2009\u03bcm and 4.5\u2009\u03bcm filters in the photometry. In this step we only focus on ID3, since the ID2 IRAC photometry is significantly contaminated by the near cluster members. The best-fitting SSP model has an age of 1.5\u2009Myr within the 2\u03c3 interval of [0.1, 30]\u2009Myr and mass of 2.2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>8</sup>\u2009\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> within [0.4, 5.2]10<sup>8</sup>\u2009\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>. For the increasing and decreasing SFH we get, respectively, \u03c4\u00a0=\u00a0\u22122.5\u2009Gyr and \u03c4\u00a0=\u00a02.5\u2009Gyr, ages of 2.5\u2009Myr within [0.1, 222]\u2009Myr and 2.5\u2009Myr within [0.1, 212]\u2009Myr, and masses of 2.2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>8</sup>\u2009\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> within [0.6, 4.7]10<sup>8</sup>\u2009\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>. In these cases, the best-fitting models require a higher \u03c4 than the previous results, in which we get \u03c4\u00a0=\u00a0\u00b10.1\u2009Gyr. However, in the Appendix (Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig15\" data-open=\"fig15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A2</a> for increasing and decreasing SFH models) we show that the probability distributions of \u03c4 are very flat, so that slight changes in the input photometry can change the best-fitting values for \u03c4 very easily. Finally, when combining all the models, the best fit is provided by the SSP model with an age of 1.5\u2009Myr within [0.1,211]\u2009Myr, and best mass of 2.2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>8</sup>\u2009\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> within [0.6,4.8]10<sup>8</sup>\u2009\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>. The metallicities and the dust contents of all the cases remain the same as in the previous results. Thus the inclusion of IRAC upper limits for ID3 leads to best-fitting parameters which are in agreement with the previous ones for all the cases, and to slightly smaller 2\u03c3 intervals for the age and mass.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To robustly compare our results with the literature, we perform the same fitting procedure (using CSPs and SSPs models) on other known <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06 lensed sources selected in the field of the CLASH clusters (i.e. Z12; R11; B13), for which we have the same photometry as for our candidate. The SED fitting performed in our work uses similar model parameters as Z12. The main difference is in the lowest model ages, which is 0.1\u2009Myr in our work and 5\u2009Myr in Z12. For the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06.2 quadruply lensed galaxy in the field of MACS0329, we get results that are consistent with Z12, for a low-mass (<em>M</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a010<sup>9</sup>\u2009\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>) young galaxy. Our best age (300\u2009Myr) is slightly higher, but still consistent within the 2\u03c3 confidence level.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">R11, unlike us, adopt in their SED fitting models a Sapleter IMF and smaller ranges for the metallicity (<em>Z</em> within [0.2, 1]\u2009Z<sub>\u2299</sub>) and ages (within 10\u2009Myr and 1\u2009Gyr). Our best age is much younger than the age range predicted in R11, although our 2\u03c3 confidence level age interval of \u223c[3, 10<sup>3</sup>]\u2009Myr covers the age range of [640,940] Myr given in R11. As a consequence, also the stellar mass is found to be quite different, given that our best value is much smaller than the mass estimated by R11(although they are anyhow consistent within our 2\u03c3 confidence level mass interval). In Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, we summarize our results for these two lensed systems, and provide the physical properties estimated in the reference works.</p>                        <a id=\"91975326\" scrollto-destination=\"91975326\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl6\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl6\" data-id=\"tbl6\"><span class=\"label\">Table\u00a06.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fitting parameters for the objects of R11 and Z12. Columns are the same as in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c4 / Gyr<span no-formula-id\">|$6.3^{+2.8}_{-1.2}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u22122\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>R11\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span work\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.5\u00a0</td><td>180\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>\u22122.50\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.06\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>Z12\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A383\u00a0</td><td>SSP\u00a0</td><td>0.005\u00a0</td><td>3.5 \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/91975326\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl6\" data-id=\"tbl6\"><span class=\"label\">Table\u00a06.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fitting parameters for the objects of R11 and Z12. .\u00a0</span></th><th>Age [age]/Myr<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>MACS0329\u00a0</td><td>0.1\u00a0</td><td>0.005\u00a0</td><td>300 [4.7,700]\u00a0</td><td>1.3 [0.2,1.5]\u00a0</td><td>\u22122.32\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>0.0\u00a0</td><td>This work\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.5\u00a0</td><td>180\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>\u22122.50\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.06\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>Z12\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A383\u00a0</td><td>SSP\u00a0</td><td>0.005\u00a0</td><td>3.5 work\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>0.5\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>[640,940]\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$6.3^{+2.8}_{-1.2}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u22122\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>R11\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c4 / Gyr<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>Z</em>/Z<sub>\u2299</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Age [age]/Myr<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>M</em><sub>*</sub>\u2009[<em>M</em><sub>*</sub>]/10<sup>9</sup>\u2009\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b2<sub>UV</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>A</em><sub>V</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Reference<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>MACS0329\u00a0</td><td>0.1\u00a0</td><td>0.005\u00a0</td><td>300 [4.7,700]\u00a0</td><td>1.3 [0.2,1.5]\u00a0</td><td>\u22122.32\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>0.0\u00a0</td><td>This work\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.5\u00a0</td><td>180\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>\u22122.50\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.06\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>Z12\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A383\u00a0</td><td>SSP\u00a0</td><td>0.005\u00a0</td><td>3.5 [2.9, 1.3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>3</sup>]\u00a0</td><td>0.2 [0.3,11.4]\u00a0</td><td>\u22122.03\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>0.8\u00a0</td><td>This work\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>0.5\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>[640,940]\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$6.3^{+2.8}_{-1.2}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u22122\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>R11\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/91975326\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We also perform the SED fitting for the 208 galaxy candidates at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06 from B13. We plot in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a> the best-fitting ages versus masses for these candidates, together with the results we get for our system, R11 and Z12. Our candidates have age and mass similar to many young candidates from B13. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a> we show the histograms for best age, with the lower- and upper-age limits, for B13 and our candidates. Although the large 2\u03c3 confidence level intervals, we see that our multiple lensed system is definitely among the young sample of <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06 galaxies. Moreover, we also estimate the UV slope \u03b2 from the best SED fitting templates for all the sources and we get that our candidate belongs to the sample of galaxies with very steep UV slope (\u03b2\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.6\u20132.9). Moreover, although the large 2\u03c3 confidence level intervals on the ages, our SED fitting suggests a very young best age for our system, compared to the other <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06 multiply lensed galaxies (Z12 and R11), while the Z12 and R11 have confirmed older ages, in agreement with the results from the literature.</p>                        <a id=\"91975328\" scrollto-destination=\"91975328\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/m_stt2284fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&amp;Signature=Sb8yphTpBmHdYLe~ragyTootVABreIgzah88rhf1qXciNW5FCxBSwJdytaCwdIYhiejw5T4EQDj0aes1c-nXwq5xNd6MqpOc3d59wsS~hE3WZUljnUa42ZSBAu1zpTE3w-T432bm1uRJ99y8mcZTHcdTV3o22mEz3XuJ-5ucC~SkLji1Uzy-86IgHIRnfvA~rQWDwGhJAYcHv8-zAU2rNxQu0Oa~vr6ZF0hisRiZ0YqupzoAlPczvrSOsuapaLXv9Gz7MTeKkMVDTTvDNmO1RDnHNJaix7DgAucK~NYLcqTw7a300Fbjz8xC-mg9hc3FBTw2mKdctFMd0FJOIwqVJg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Age and mass results for SED fitting runs with all SFHs combined on the objects from the literature and the system discussed in this paper. The plot shows the objects of R11 (green triangle), Z12 (blue square), B13 (black diamonds) and ID2&amp;3 (red points). Error bars show the intervals in mass and age within which the total probability reads 95.45\u2009 per cent (corresponding to a 2\u03c3 confidence interval). To improve on the clarity of the figure we did not plot the intervals for the B13 objects.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig12.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91975328/stt2284fig12.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig12.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91975328\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/stt2284fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&Signature=XR4Y7NNyx9QPjRAcJ~8zQjCHjj3NurW-jVkVoDbJLXhIydt3RQR2aN3AWIgeedmlm7waW3nqm6rZWWdw2PTllWgpn1-bssu47U9DvXrElGw-RkET5k98feQ5j6mvatQ89CBMIYV-TunEyNOIt11rd8qMGjuRStRWZhY~VaVfKoynCrtvvFUxRp-1VyqpTJbPCPC-ExEF2MMiB693jbRYqhKt1xg3JJbXOlFgv72a061hlyXxYXvEyqH3b6bGLdeOY1DlQp0qW~~nZQ99L4pOPhjS2t8Jw1937gzEzfkGcx5x32JtxBD6aMxk4rx3yVX2v7lc46D3YJhsAO6GGbDb9Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91975328&ar=1010021&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig12.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Age and mass results for SED fitting runs with all SFHs combined on the objects from the literature and the system discussed in this paper. Lower panel: histogram of the UV slope \u03b2 as measured from the best-fitting SED templates for the B13 candidates (in black) and for our high-z galaxy (in green).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig13.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91975329/stt2284fig13.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig13.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91975329\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/stt2284fig13.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&Signature=Ik0A4HpC2v16AOy3UBZpklEEDIBYc~w4kOkMtVR2HAiKcIpxQWNpOn~aY6Rm0N3n~8BEpNYZT93dHcMMgBYdV8G3CSsh8cPdV1PH9j0o2-xQq~J8e76QDNkmpRoWhPKprJOuhOSuH1648KHuosu8akkrhu~vzEmSvr~vYtr26PF7m0u9sLEgWxOM5zPtBDhme7ZeBoYfDce9AZRNtzwD79MLc1~1Dr7uYMLOTfypTTisBp8POSdpLX4HtY6uCoUnrqs53nN2lX-8bQ3sE4WX8BEfx8uyB28qKckanHNjXhKQ~0dpSkVMspjQSCweHWxFLA-wxM08-Y4KRBjponF4sA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91975329&ar=1010021&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284fig13.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Upper panel: histogram of the best ages for the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06 candidates from R11, Z12 and B13 (in black). We plot in light and dark blue the age lower and upper limits, respectively, for the 2\u03c3 confidence level intervals of the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06 candidates. In green we plot ID2&amp;3. The 2\u03c3 confidence level intervals are too large to well constrain the ages of the sources; however our multiple lensed system surely belongs to the young sample of <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06 galaxies. Lower panel: histogram of the UV slope \u03b2 as measured from the best-fitting SED templates for the B13 candidates (in black) and for our high-<em>z</em> galaxy (in green).</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91975330 id=\"91975330\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec8>SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We report the discovery of a young quintuply lensed galaxy candidate at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06 in the field of the galaxy cluster RXC J2248 (<em>z</em><sub>cl</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.348). We identify this system as four i-dropouts, plus a central lensed image which we detect once we remove the BCG from the data set images. The lensed images have colours consistent within the errors, which are in agreement with the colour prediction for SB galaxies at <em>z</em> &gt; 5. Moreover, they have photometric redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06, with a well-defined peak in the PDF(<em>z</em>) and no photo-<em>z</em> solution at low-<em>z</em>. We perform the strong lensing analysis of the cluster, using 11 systems of multiple images as constraints, and we find that our model predicts the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06 multiple lensed system with an accuracy of 0.8 arcsec. The magnifications predicted for the lensed images are between 2.2 and 8.3. Referring to the two images with the best photometry, we estimate the delensed UV luminosity to be <em>L</em><sub>UV</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.5<em>L</em>* at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a06. From the observed NIR colours, we estimate the UV slope of our source to be \u03b2\u00a0=\u00a0\u22122.89\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.38. We perform a SED fitting of the observed photometry, using SSPs and CSPs SED templates, and derive that our candidate has subsolar metallicity (<em>Z</em>/Z<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.2), low dust content (<em>A</em><sub><em>V</em></sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.2\u20130.4), stellar mass M\u223c10<sup>8</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> and best age of \u223c1\u2009Myr. Although the age is not well constrained, we can set an upper limit of \u223c300\u2009Myr, given the 2\u03c3 uncertainties that we get. We verify that including the shallow IRAC photometric upper limits in the SED fitting leads to similar results, with slightly smaller 2\u03c3 intervals on the mass and age. We finally compare our predicted ages and masses, with the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06 candidates selected up to date in the field of all CLASH clusters, and we find that our multiply lensed galaxy has a young age and low mass, similar to some of the objects from B13. However, compared to the other known multiply lensed <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06 galaxies, our SED fitting suggests a younger age for our multiple lensed system. This source adds to the several multiple lensed objects known at high-<em>z</em>, characterized for being five times lensed, with a central image identified in the very inner region of the lensing cluster.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">After the submission of the paper to the journal, three multiple images of this system (ID2,3,4) have been spectroscopically confirmed at <em>z</em> = 6.11 by Balestra et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) in a dedicated VIMOS Large Programme to follow-up CLASH high-<em>z</em> objects. An independent redshift measurement with VLT/FORS2 is also reported in Boone et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), who initially associated this system with a bright sub-mm LABOCA source. Such an association is not supported by the spectroscopic properties described in Balestra et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and the hard UV slope reported in this paper.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This work is supported by the Transregional Collaborative Research Centre TRR 33 - The Dark Universe and the DFG cluster of excellence \u2018Origin and Structure of the Universe\u2019. The CLASH Multi-Cycle Treasury Program (GO-12065) is based on observations made with the NASA/ESA <em>HST</em>. The Space Telescope Science Institute is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc. under NASA contract NAS 5-26555. The Dark Cosmology Centre is funded by the DNRF. Support for AZ is provided by NASA through Hubble Fellowship grant HST-HF-51334.01-A awarded by STScI. He was also partly supported by contract research \u2018Internationale Spitzenforschung II/2-6\u2019 of the Baden W\u00fcrttemberg Stiftung.</p><div content-id=\"fn1a\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1a\" class=\"end-note-link\">\u2020</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Hubble Fellow.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.stsci.edu/hst/campaigns/frontier-fields/\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.stsci.edu/hst/campaigns/frontier-fields/</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Using the formula <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$N=\\sqrt{S + n_{\\rm pix}\\times B}$|\u2060</span>, where <em>N</em> is the noise, <em>S</em> is the signal, <em>n</em><sub>pix</sub> is the number of pixels in the aperture and <em>B</em> is the background per pixel.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn3\" openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://archive.stsci.edu/prepds/clash/\" target=\"_blank\">http://archive.stsci.edu/prepds/clash/</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn5\"><span class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://iraf.noao.edu/\" target=\"_blank\">http://iraf.noao.edu/</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn6\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn6\" class=\"end-note-link\">6</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">See <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://astronomy.nmsu.edu/holtz/xvista/index.html\" target=\"_blank\">http://astronomy.nmsu.edu/holtz/xvista/index.html</a> and Lauer (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1986</a>).</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn7\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn7\" class=\"end-note-link\">7</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.cida.ve/~bruzual/bc2003\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.cida.ve/~bruzual/bc2003</a> or <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.iap.fr/~charlot/bc2003\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.iap.fr/~charlot/bc2003</a></p></div></span></div>                    <h2 target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1088%2F2041-8205%2F747%2F1%2FL9\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91975346 id=\"91975346\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec9>APPENDIX A: SED FITTING RESULTS</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We show here the results of the SED fitting from Section\u00a07 of the multiple lensed system in greater detail. We concentrate again only on ID2&amp;3 which have the cleanest photometry. Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig15\" data-open=\"fig15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A2</a> display the results for exponentially increasing (\u03c4\u00a0&lt;\u00a00) and decreasing (\u03c4 &gt; 0) SFRs. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig16\" data-open=\"fig16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A3</a> shows the fitting results with SSP models only, whereas Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig17\" data-open=\"fig17\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A4</a> displays the results when we perform the SED fit to all models (SSPs and CSPs) combined. The lower panels of Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a> to <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig17\" data-open=\"fig17\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A4</a> display the best-fitting SED and the photometry. The panels in the middle and upper rows show the two-dimensional likelihood distributions of fitting parameters (<em>Z</em>, \u03c4, model age, <em>A</em><sub>V</sub>), whereas the probability distributions of the mass-to-light ratios (<em>M</em>/<em>L</em>) in the <em>V</em> band are shown in the upper panels. The blue contours in the likelihood distributions outline the 1\u03c3 (solid), 2\u03c3 (dashed) and 3\u03c3 (dotted) confidence levels. The filter bands in which the S/N does not exceed 1 (the dropout filters f225w to f775w) are considered upper limits in the SED fit (lower panels).</p>                        <a id=\"91975348\" scrollto-destination=\"91975348\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig14\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/m_stt2284figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&amp;Signature=UWak~cCqSda6HbKIeVKFJ-Bk1~Fp8i53Vd2S9C~7Q165Es7kfXq0Fe3stN5ZfOOXxsWWzHkkOh5pugtB9uZyCdZGUnK34T3O~xtaTTslkPMlKHzlitVd-8C9LTu2vT-6-D-rw45ZlIEwQpFshnp4gbNT5ReXh93eN2SY-X1caCQBUABGhnE2o-kNZB6UgAf3O7jnGNNjf-6mtYyr7KX9nKUYaAGwmSZcDh3iaKH01jvFV07dtiq7M1XC5XnGw485~bK7jGC15wmq6oKhRzdCqg66Hs3BJM8eukg6qPxYwIaY34LvgugNljLRrmCaEUa8zOulTuoBlWDfVugF17oLBQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SED fitting results for ID2&amp;3 and models with negative \u03c4 SFRs. The lower panel shows the input photometry and errors with black points. Empty circles denote the fluxes in the dropout filters where the fluxes are considered upper limits. The best-fitting model SED is shown in blue and the convolved fluxes in the detection bands are displayed by filled circles. The density plots in the upper panels show the likelihood distributions of the SED fit in two-dimensional parameter spaces. Blue lines denote the 1\u03c3 (dotted), 2\u03c3 (dashed) and 3\u03c3 (solid) confidence levels. Finally, the likelihood distribution of the M/L in the V band is plotted in the upper right panel. The dotted line in this panel denotes the M/L of the best-fitting model.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284figa1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91975348/stt2284figa1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284figa1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91975348\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/stt2284figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&Signature=dhnjPdXhVt2M1i7m0ql5VMFi9d1XkRTT6CTllwsVNjnUPNbCFkA7aQp0BD9j4uh-DiNQsgK2zwbO07TuvGbFWMFzU5KLgTr16U4~DgRU~lGGmzcnZm4RepwTZIt4UOy1Ch0kAvZ5ccEtoYTumO-LTU80qzl-kBw0xo7OxWYzp~vgChSnrn1nvz~pBw3K9c5MlIqrd1oawF6yGvuYkB8juUaNF-8YbHPTRsRQ7~D6tl9Qlipk3BXkNFZX6P8NI7d99h6UU4YUDrFlt2VQTxopAZzRpWbhd0OPre0v5Y~naodAxQox-s6tOqZU1tPWXYXO2U1QIzWGO5Tuqp~qtt8bhg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91975348&ar=1010021&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284figa1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SED fitting results for ID2&amp;3 and models with negative \u03c4 SFRs. The lower panel shows the input photometry and errors with black points. Empty circles denote the fluxes in the dropout filters where the fluxes are considered upper limits. The best-fitting model SED is shown in blue and the convolved fluxes in the detection bands are displayed by filled circles. The density plots in the upper panels show the likelihood distributions of the SED fit in two-dimensional parameter spaces. Blue lines denote the 1\u03c3 (dotted), 2\u03c3 (dashed) and 3\u03c3 (solid) confidence levels. Finally, the likelihood distribution of the <em>M/L</em> in the <em>V</em> band is plotted in the upper right panel. The dotted line in this panel denotes the <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> of the best-fitting model.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig14\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/m_stt2284figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&amp;Signature=UWak~cCqSda6HbKIeVKFJ-Bk1~Fp8i53Vd2S9C~7Q165Es7kfXq0Fe3stN5ZfOOXxsWWzHkkOh5pugtB9uZyCdZGUnK34T3O~xtaTTslkPMlKHzlitVd-8C9LTu2vT-6-D-rw45ZlIEwQpFshnp4gbNT5ReXh93eN2SY-X1caCQBUABGhnE2o-kNZB6UgAf3O7jnGNNjf-6mtYyr7KX9nKUYaAGwmSZcDh3iaKH01jvFV07dtiq7M1XC5XnGw485~bK7jGC15wmq6oKhRzdCqg66Hs3BJM8eukg6qPxYwIaY34LvgugNljLRrmCaEUa8zOulTuoBlWDfVugF17oLBQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SED fitting results for ID2&amp;3 and models with negative \u03c4 SFRs. The dashed lines are the ages of the best-fitting models. Between the dotted lines the total probability is 95.45\u2009 per cent (corresponding to a 2\u03c3 confidence interval).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig18\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/m_stt2284figa5.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&amp;Signature=C5sNePQS0dILCsJNN0nondh28sq37cgYl4Oy2PCDfxsx95V1AkStimUUvcuUUDfzs-SmDJPZ6-kr~R3c2Yuy2auy90MACBpZexohDaaQyhsSxYZp9rgPeGlxgWU4kyPSa2GlMU~b4RS2vg2V7CtARGP3jVOxbor~qikwhtPfbZZEwhCkD3OmtzVWvTv1FTBYIYTKIEj3czqaMty5SzfNlI1EmsWulws4~ojWTyG4GxMndE23c8OyezIZ1mFsUJb3~LDeSE~Kk4VjEnSps3RhhjDLXgo~bzCoGb5vKLmIAAlYEbgX52Sr5tkcoPBRXnYKN~MDrVEYZAXBoeFAk6jAiQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"PDF of the model age for ID2&amp;3, marginalized over the other fitting parameters for a fit with \u03c4\u00a0&lt;\u00a00 SFR models. The dashed lines are the ages of the best-fitting models. Between the dotted lines the total probability is 95.45\u2009 per cent (corresponding to a 2\u03c3 confidence interval).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284figa5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91975352/stt2284figa5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284figa5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91975352\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/stt2284figa5.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&Signature=VZsTkAfZ-pLcnbCaIIyrp7s7nD7gMd8kn9Ajrfz7x2wJoE~FePnnLc6DhL~CeI-oshy46~VXEM5QdOXgv23jFk96nfaOlHrgmb~mZQrHCe4WchWcvf35SLOfUtIFCBkB58t89cRWaol7yfNsYOubc3cLY~mBC-a3k84FJQ6x6oZkJr0qoq3w-wIGaU3Deu8WEYdsrlxgAoWYbHd8UJjfgS6XID6FOacoJVr7LETV9D0cJZB9cEy1hSepYowg1-p-Da16yUoBjSmUXHBQM-eNYSTvEbFkIPSxozJen7S2TmfETGf-IvBcUc2vQ-~CC6e5ZOzr0aZ~76fJ4DQp2ahXVA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91975352&ar=1010021&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284figa5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">PDF of the model age for ID2&amp;3, marginalized over the other fitting parameters for a fit with \u03c4\u00a0&lt;\u00a00 SFR models. The dashed lines are the ages of the best-fitting models. Between the dotted lines the total probability is 95.45\u2009 per cent (corresponding to a 2\u03c3 confidence interval).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig19\" data-open=\"fig19\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A5</a> to <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig21\" data-open=\"fig21\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A8</a> show furthermore the probability distributions of the model ages, marginalized over the other fitting parameters. The upper limits of the 2\u03c3 interval in age is smallest for the fit with SSP models (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig20\" data-open=\"fig20\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A7</a>). This is because all stars are assumed to form at the time of formation and therefore the mean stellar age of a SSP is higher than that of a CSP with the same formation redshift observed at the same cosmic time.</p>                        <a id=\"91975354\" scrollto-destination=\"91975354\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig19\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/m_stt2284figa6.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&amp;Signature=uxph3Vj1wkOJe5jtWGpecpUrVAEOv2RsuljPswyf2Y7SLZxiqy707wf1yC~2t5EH3ttG1D0MtsS7OYxQnlP1I7VLn-UIovLKBVOsvGKHXEsKDxAF7ByLiLeZRXf~MKVu62US7wouCNcphse5ybYDF7gUSLg1FtOdvmabbD1RGzy-X2tdyB2FQANi2vTeDpjrOhAsYgnSYZL4wCmaEf2lkro7rNeRzEYNapLjoTAcTIkzuis7qQ4XWlZGPSwIvHR2zo6MagN2loYKW0kj8vDEgLkmig~4uN4WNlxQnpXTD3iGOzlDx4YPQdk-JHTieCkrBfWOgc1dvoE3tI~ASWUjfw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"PDF of the model age for ID2&amp;3, marginalized over the other fitting parameters for a fit with \u03c4 &gt; 0 SFR models. The dashed lines are the ages of the best-fitting models. Between the dotted lines the total probability is 95.45\u2009 per cent (corresponding to a 2\u03c3 confidence interval).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284figa6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91975354/stt2284figa6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284figa6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91975354\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/438/2/10.1093_mnras_stt2284/2/stt2284figa6.jpeg?Expires=1611467749&Signature=muiZCowTBJg-yjDBrChL0CNnZ7OicfXD5GULG2Gc7jmmZBSbt2aF7z3UGqTyTIazsEmuXdALNnk3o03~DdauIU8X5gh5-p3-dWY7nSqqiMa8vjPnJqELVe6lCyYjw1V-z59X5O9WbgheH~oNmcjtRj-U7lK6USfYWTHZHpUsjWUTE5LOvCsPuwgilZhE3baKrNeZhJJ65cOIAwz6ZNEn8MUvmZlthfc4-yoZ06NVW3JyipScvM-oHGeWN7rrEprHS0kOXydr0QFeD8vdJS19t107vcDuIk2MGZfRtQ5mWRXBK8lZ9zBe257Rpf9J-f9BUQkePHwBqImz88JgLW7SgA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91975354&ar=1010021&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stt2284figa6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">PDF of the model age for ID2&amp;3, marginalized over the other fitting parameters for a fit with \u03c4 &gt; 0 SFR models.
